message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has hemolytic anemia, which is confirmed by the presence of spherocytes on the peripheral blood smear and the positive direct antiglobulin test. The undetectable haptoglobin and elevated lactate dehydrogenase further support this diagnosis. The most likely cause of this hemolysis is drug-induced immune hemolytic anemia, considering the recent use of cephalexin. Oral prednisone is the most appropriate next step in treatment to suppress the immune system and reduce hemolysis. Splenectomy may be considered in severe cases, and plasmapheresis and intravenous immune globulin can be used for acute exacerbations.
